column1: The Gold Coast is a coastal city in the Australian state of Queensland
column2: approximately 66 kilometres (41 mi) south-southeast of the centre of state capital Brisbane and immediately north of the border with New South Wales. The demonym for the Gold Coast is Gold Coaster. With an estimated population of 679
column4: at June 2019 (including 79
column5: 001 in the adjacent Tweed Valley of New South Wales)
column6: the Gold Coast is the sixth-largest city in Australia
column7: making it the largest non-capital city
column8: and Queensland's second-largest city.Gold Coast is a major tourist destination with a sunny
column9: subtropical climate and has become widely known for its world-class surfing beaches
column13: and rainforest hinterland. The city is part of the nation's entertainment industry with television productions and a major film industry. The city hosted the 2018 Commonwealth Games which ran from 4 to 15 April 2018.

column1: == History ==
The Gold Coast is the ancestral home of a number of Indigenous clans of the Yugambeh people
column2: including the Kombumerri
column3: Bullongin
column4: and Tulgi-gi-gin clans.Lieutenant James Cook became the first European to note the region when he sailed along the coast on 16 May 1770 in HMS Endeavour. Captain Matthew Flinders
column5: an explorer charting the continent north from the colony of New South Wales
column6: sailed past in 1802. Escaped convicts from the Moreton Bay penal settlement hid in the region. The region remained largely uninhabited by Europeans until 1823 when explorer John Oxley landed at Mermaid Beach
column7: which was named after seeing a cutter named Mermaid. The hinterland's red cedar supply attracted people to the area in the mid-19th century.

column1: A number of small townships developed along coast and in the hinterland. The western suburb of Nerang was surveyed and established as a base for the industry and by 1870 a town reserve had been set aside. By 1873
column2: the town reserve of Burleigh Heads had also been surveyed and successful land sales had taken place. In 1875
column3: the small settlement opposite the boat passage at the head of the Nerang River
column4: known as Nerang Heads or Nerang Creek Heads
column6: with the first land sales scheduled to take place in Beenleigh. Southport quickly grew a reputation as a secluded holiday destination for wealthy Brisbane residents. After the establishment of the Surfers Paradise Hotel in the late 1920s
column7: the Gold Coast region grew significantly.The Gold Coast was originally known as the South Coast (because it was south of Brisbane). However
column8: inflated prices for real estate and other goods and services led to the nickname of "Gold Coast" from 1950. South Coast locals initially considered the name "Gold Coast" derogatory. However
column9: soon the "Gold Coast" simply became a convenient way to refer to the holiday strip from Southport to Coolangatta. The Town of South Coast was formed through the amalgamation of Town of Coolangatta and Town of Southport along with the coastal areas (such as Burleigh Heads) from the Shire of Nerang on 17 June 1949 with the effect of having the present-day Gold Coast coastal strip as a single local government area. As the tourism industry grew into the 1950s
column10: local businesses began to adopt the term Gold Coast in their names
column11: and on 23 October 1958 the Town of South Coast was renamed Town of Gold Coast. The area was proclaimed a city less than one year later on 16 May 1959.The area boomed in the 1980s as a leading tourist destination. In 1994
column12: the City of Gold Coast local government area was expanded to include the Shire of Albert
column13: becoming the second most populous local government area in Australia after the City of Brisbane.In 2007
column14: the Gold Coast overtook the population of Newcastle
column16: to become the sixth largest city in Australia and the largest non-capital city.The Gold Coast hosted the 2018 Commonwealth Games.

column1: == Geography ==
The Gold Coast is approximately half covered by forests of various types. This includes small patches of near-pristine ancient rainforest
column2: mangrove-covered islands
column3: and patches of coastal heathlands and farmland with areas of uncleared eucalyptus forest. Of the plantation pine forests that were planted in the 1950s and 1960s
column4: when commercial forest planting for tax minimisation was encouraged by the Commonwealth government
column5: tiny remnants remain.Gold Coast City lies in the southeast corner of Queensland
column7: the state capital. The Albert River separates the Gold Coast from Logan City
column8: a local government area south of the City of Brisbane.

column1: Gold Coast City stretches from the Albert River
column2: Logan River
column3: and Southern Moreton Bay to the border with New South Wales (NSW) approximately 56 km (35 mi) south
column4: and extends from the coast west to the foothills of the Great Dividing Range in World Heritage listed Lamington National Park.

column1: The southernmost town of Gold Coast City
column2: Coolangatta
column3: includes Point Danger and its lighthouse. Coolangatta is a twin city with Tweed Heads located directly across the NSW border. At 28.1667°S 153.55°E﻿ / -28.1667; 153.55
column4: this is the most easterly point on the Queensland mainland (Point Lookout on the offshore island of North Stradbroke is slightly further east). From Coolangatta
column5: approximately forty kilometres of holiday resorts and surfing beaches stretch north to the suburb of Main Beach
column6: and then further on Stradbroke Island. The suburbs of Southport and Surfers Paradise form the Gold Coast's commercial centre. The major river in the area is the Nerang River. Much of the land between the coastal strip and the hinterland were once wetlands drained by this river
column7: but the swamps have been converted into man-made waterways (over 260 kilometres (160 mi) in length or over 9 times the length of the canals of Venice
column8: Italy) and artificial islands covered in upmarket homes. The heavily developed coastal strip sits on a narrow barrier sandbar between these waterways and the sea.

column1: To the west
column2: the city borders a part of the Great Dividing Range commonly referred to as the Gold Coast hinterland. A 206 km2 (80 sq mi) section of the mountain range is protected by Lamington National Park and has been listed as a World Heritage area in recognition of its "outstanding geological features displayed around shield volcanic craters and the high number of rare and threatened rainforest species". The area attracts bushwalkers and day-trippers. Important rainforest pollinating and seed-dispersing Black flying foxes (Pteropus alecto) are found in the area and may be heard foraging at night.

column1: === Urban structure ===
The City of Gold Coast includes suburbs
column2: localities
column3: towns and rural districts.

column1: The declaration of Southport as a Priority Development Area (PDA) and new investment into the CBD is driving transformative change and creating new business and investment opportunities.
=== Waterways ===
Waterfront canal living is a feature of the Gold Coast. Most canal frontage homes have pontoons. The Gold Coast Seaway
column2: between The Spit and South Stradbroke Island
column3: allows vessels direct access to the Pacific Ocean from The Broadwater and many of the city's canal estates. Breakwaters on either side of the Seaway prevent longshore drift and the bar from silting up. A sand pumping operation on the Spit pipes sand under the Seaway to continue this natural process.

column1: Residential canals were first built in the Gold Coast in the 1950s and construction continues. Most canals are extensions to the Nerang River
column2: but there are more to the south along Tallebudgera Creek and Currumbin Creek and to the north along the Gold Coast Broadwater
column3: South Stradbroke Island
column4: Coomera River and southern Moreton Bay. Early canals included Florida Gardens and Isle of Capri which were under construction at the time of a 1954 flood. Recently constructed canals include Harbour Quays and Riverlinks completed in 2007. There are over 890 kilometres (550 mi) of constructed residential waterfront land within the city that is home to over 80

The city consists of 70 kilometres (43 mi) of coastline

column4: The Spit
column7: Broadbeach
column8: Mermaid Beach
column22: Snapper Rocks and Froggies Beach. Duranbah Beach is one of the world's best known surfing beaches and is often thought of as being part of Gold Coast City
column23: but is actually just across the New South Wales state border in the Tweed Shire.

column1: There are also beaches along many of the Gold Coast's 860 km (530 mi) of navigable tidal waterways. Popular inland beaches include Southport

column1: Beach safety and management

The Gold Coast has Australia's largest professional surf lifesaving service to protect people on the beaches and to promote surf safety throughout the community. The Queensland Department of Primary Industries carries out the Queensland Shark Control Program (SCP) to protect swimmers from sharks. Sharks are caught by using nets and baited drumlines off the major swimming beaches. Even with the SCP
column2: sharks do range within sight of the patrolled beaches. Lifeguards will clear swimmers from the water if it is considered that there is a safety risk.

column1: Gold Coast beaches have experienced periods of severe beach erosion. In 1967
column2: a series of 11 cyclones removed most of the sand from Gold Coast beaches. The Government of Queensland engaged engineers from Delft University in the Netherlands to advise what to do about the beach erosion. The Delft Report was published in 1971 and outlined a series of works for Gold Coast Beaches including Gold Coast Seaway
column3: works at Narrow Neck that resulted in the Northern Gold Coast Beach Protection Strategy and works at the Tweed River that became the Tweed River Entrance Sand Bypassing Project.By 2005 most of the recommendations of the 1971 Delft Report had been implemented. City of Gold Coast commenced implementation of the Palm Beach Protection Strategy but ran into considerable opposition from the community participating in a NO REEF protest campaign. The City of Gold Coast Council then committed to completing a review of beach management practices to update the Delft Report. The Gold Coast Shoreline Management Plan will be delivered by organisations including the Environmental Protection Agency
column4: City of Gold Coast and the Griffith Centre for Coastal Management. Gold Coast City is also investing into the quality and capacity of the Gold Coast Oceanway that provides sustainable transport along Gold Coast beaches.

column1: === Climate ===
The Gold Coast experiences a humid subtropical climate (Köppen climate classification Cfa)
column2: with mild winters and hot
column3: humid summers. The city experiences substantial summer precipitation mostly concentrated in thunderstorms and heavy showers with rain events occasionally lasting up to a few weeks at a time giving residents "the summer blues"
column4: while winter is pleasantly mild to warm with little rain. In fact
column5: it is for this pleasant winter weather that both the city and the Sunshine Coast—the coastal region north of Brisbane—are internationally renowned. Extreme temperatures recorded at Gold Coast Seaway have ranged from 0.6 °C (33 °F) on 18 June 2018 to 40.5 °C (105 °F) on 22 February 2005
column6: although the city rarely experiences temperatures above 35 °C (95 °F) in summer or below 5 °C (41 °F) in winter. The average temperature of the sea at Surfers Paradise ranges from 21.5 °C (70.7 °F) in July and August to 27.1 °C (80.8 °F) in February.

column15: and Cantonese (0.5%). The most common religious affiliations reported were none (31.8%)

column1: == Government ==
Administratively
column2: the Gold Coast is a local government area called the City of Gold Coast. The City of Gold Coast Council has 14 elected councillors
column3: each representing a division of the City. Businessman Tom Tate is the current Mayor of the Gold Coast
column4: first elected in 2012. Former mayors include Ron Clake
column7: Ray Stevens
column8: Ern Harley and Sir Bruce Small
column9: who was responsible for the development of many of the canal estates that are now home to thousands of Gold Coast residents.

column1: At the state level
column2: the Gold Coast area is represented by eleven members in the Legislative Assembly of Queensland. The seats they hold are: Bonney
column3: Broadwater
column4: Burleigh
column7: Gaven
column8: Mermaid Beach
column12: the Gold Coast area is split between five divisions in the House of Representatives: Fadden (northern)
column13: Moncrieff (central) and McPherson (southern) are located entirely within the Gold Coast
column14: while Forde (north-west) and Wright (south-west) encompass parts of the Gold Coast and other areas of Southeast Queensland.

column1: Politically
column2: the Gold Coast has often tilted conservative. It was a Country Party bastion for most of the first three decades after World War II
column3: but increasing urbanisation has made it a Liberal stronghold. Labor has historically only done well around Labrador and Coolangatta. Only one Labor MP has ever represented a significant portion of the Gold Coast at the federal level since 1949; the three Gold Coast divisions have only returned Liberals since 1984. At the state level
column4: Labor was fairly competitive in the Gold Coast for most of the early part of the 21st century. However
column5: as part of its massive landslide in the 2012 state election
column6: the Liberal National Party won every seat there. The LNP repeated its sweep of the Gold Coast seats at the 2015 election
column7: and retained all but one Gold Coast seat at the 2017 state election.

column1: Southport Courthouse is the city's major courthouse and has jurisdiction to hear petty criminal offences and civil matters up to A$250
column2: 000. Indictable offences
column3: criminal sentencing and civil matters above A$250
column4: 000 are heard in the higher Supreme Court of Queensland which is located in Brisbane. There is also a subsidiary Magistrates Court
column5: located at the southern suburb of Coolangatta.

column1: In 2013 a brawl between members of Outlaw motorcycle gangs also called "bikies" who fought each other outside a Broadbeach restaurant caused mass fear to restaurant patrons and police. This led to the toughest anti-bikie laws introduced in Australia known as Vicious Lawless Association Disestablishment Act 2013.
== Economy ==
In fifty years
column2: Gold Coast City has grown from a small beachside holiday destination to Australia's sixth largest city (and the country's most populous non-capital city). Situated within South East Queensland's growth corridor
column3: the Gold Coast is one of Australia's fastest growing large cities
column4: with a 5-year annual average population growth rate to 2015 of 1.8%
column5: compared to 1.5% nationally. Gross Regional Product has risen from A$9.7 billion in 2001
column7: a rise of 61 percent. Tourism remains fundamental to Gold Coast City's economy
column8: with almost 10 million visitors a year to the area. In the past the economy was driven by the population derived industries of construction
column9: tourism and retail. Some diversification has taken place
column10: with the city now having an industrial base formed of marine
column16: environment and sports industries. These nine industries have been identified as the key industries by the City of Gold Coast Council to deliver the city's economic prosperity. Gold Coast City's unemployment rate (5.6 per cent) is below the national level (5.9 per cent). The declaration of Southport as the Gold Coast central business district (CBD) and a Priority Development Area (PDA)
column17: as well as new investment into the CBD
column18: is driving transformative change and creating new business and investment opportunities.

column1: Since the opening of what was then the world's highest residential tower in 2005 (it is now the fifth highest)
column2: the Q1 building has been a destination for tourists and locals alike. It is the second highest public vantage point in the southern hemisphere after the Eureka Tower in Melbourne. The observation deck at level 77 is the highest of its kind in Queensland and offers views in all directions
column3: from Brisbane to Byron Bay. It towers over the Surfers Paradise skyline
column4: with the observation deck 230 metres (755 feet) high
column5: and the spire extending nearly another hundred metres up. In total
column6: the Q1 is 322.5 metres (1058 feet) high
column7: making it the tallest building in Australia. Another famous tourist attraction are the Surfers Paradise Meter Maids
column8: instituted in 1965 to put a positive spin on new parking regulations. To avoid tickets being issued for expired parking
column9: the Meter Maids dispense coins into the meter and leave a calling card under the windscreen wiper of the vehicle. The Maids are still a part of the Surfers Paradise culture but the scheme is now run by private enterprise.

column1: === Film production ===
The Gold Coast is the major film production hub in Queensland and has accounted for 75% of all film production in Queensland since the 1990s
column2: with an expenditure of around $150 million per year. The Gold Coast is the third largest film production centre in Australia behind Sydney and Melbourne.

column1: It is the filming site for major motion pictures including Scooby Doo (2002)
column2: House of Wax (2005)
column3: Superman Returns (2006)
column4: Unbroken (2014)
column6: San Andreas (2015) Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)
column7: Kong: Skull Island (2017)
column8: Thor: Ragnarok (2017)
column11: Dora the Explorer (2019) and Godzilla vs. Kong (2020).Village Roadshow Studios are adjacent to the Warner Bros Movie World Theme Park at Oxenford. The Studios consists of eight sound stages
column16: water tanks and commissary. These sound stages vary in size and have an overall floor area of 10
column18: making Warner Roadshow Studio one of the largest studio lots in the Southern Hemisphere. The Queensland Government actively supports the film and television production industry in Queensland and provides both non-financial and financial assistance through the Pacific Film and Television Commission.

column1: == Culture ==
The Gold Coast's culture has been impacted by rapid development and traditional marketing programs orbiting around 'sun
column2: sand
column3: surf and sex.'Despite rapid socio-economic changes and a tourist-centred image
column4: there is evidence of local resident-driven culture (such as surf gangs) in geographical pockets and a broader 'Gold Coaster' identity drawn from globalised resort and real estate marketing material. The Gold Coast hosts cultural activities that attract tourists and residents alike.

column1: === Music ===

Home of the Arts (HOTA) is the Gold Coast's premier cultural facility for visual and performing arts with a performance theatre
column2: two cinemas and an underground venue. The theatre has hosted performance by the Imperial Russian Ballet
column3: The Australian Ballet and the Queensland Ballet. Musicals
column4: plays and a variety of performances are regularly scheduled. The city is also home to the Gold Coast City Art Gallery. Film festivals and the Comedy Club host international artists. A redeveloped Gold Coast cultural precinct opened before the city hosted the 2018 Commonwealth Games.Bleach* The Gold Coast Festival takes place annually across the City in August. The program is one of Australia's leading and most exciting site-specific contemporary arts programs. Quintessentially Gold Coast

column7: 000 people since its inaugural year in 2012. The program features work across all genres including dance

column1: === Commonwealth Games ===

The 2018 Commonwealth Games was held on the Gold Coast between 4 and 15 April 2018 which was an international multi-sport event for members of the Commonwealth. It was the fifth time Australia had hosted the Commonwealth Games and the first time a major multi-sport event achieved gender equality by having an equal number of events for male and female athletes. More than 4
column2: 400 athletes including 300 para-athletes from 71 Commonwealth Games Associations took part in the event.The venues such as Carrara Stadium

column4: Carrara Indoor Sports Stadium
column5: Gold Coast City Convention and Exhibition Centre. Broadbeach Bowls Club Nerang Mountain Bike Trails
column7: Oxenford Studios
column8: The Gold Coast Hockey Centre
column13: and Coolangatta Beachfront were used for the Games.

column1: == Media ==
Print

The daily local newspaper is the Gold Coast Bulletin which is published by News Corporation. National surfing magazine Australia's Surfing Life is published in the Gold Coast suburb of Burleigh Heads by Morrison Media.
Television

column2: Nine's QTQ and 10's TVQ
column3: while the regional affiliates are Prime7's NEN
column4: NBN Television and WIN Television.

== Education ==
=== Colleges and universities ===

The Gold Coast is home to two major university campuses: Bond University at Robina and Griffith University at Southport. Southern Cross University also operates a smaller campus in Bilinga near the Gold Coast Airport. The Gold Coast Institute of Technical and Further Education (TAFE) has five campuses at Southport
column2: Ridgeway (Ashmore)
column3: Benowa
column4: Coomera and Coolangatta.

column1: === Schools and libraries ===
There are over 100 primary and secondary schools
column2: both public and private and of a variety of denominations
column3: including the selective state high school Queensland Academy for Health Sciences and single-sex private schools The Southport School and St Hilda's School. The longest established public school on the Gold Coast is Southport State High School
column4: having originally opened in 1916. There are a number of libraries located on the Gold Coast. For a full list see Gold Coast libraries.

column1: == Infrastructure ==
=== Utilities ===
Electricity

Electricity for the Gold Coast is sourced from Powerlink Queensland at bulk supply substations which is provided via the National Electricity Market from an interconnected multi-State power system. The Government-owned electricity corporation Energex distributes and retails electricity
column2: natural gas
column3: liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) and value-added products and services to residential
column4: industrial and commercial customers in South-East Queensland.

column1: Water supply
The Hinze Dam 15 km (9.3 mi) southwest of Nerang is the population's main water supply. The Little Nerang Dam which feeds into Hinze Dam can supplement part of the city area's water needs
column2: and both are managed by the city council directorate Gold Coast Water. Reforms of the way in which the water industry is structured have been announced by the State Government
column3: with transfer of ownership and management of water services from local government to the state occurring in 2008–09. City of Gold Coast also sources water from Wivenhoe Dam
column4: west of Brisbane for northern suburbs when the Hinze Dam

column1: Water shortage and water restrictions have been current local issues
column2: and a few new Gold Coast residential areas have recently included dual reticulation in their planning and development to supply water from a new water recycling plant being built concurrently. This will make available highly treated recycled water for use around the home in addition to potable water. The Gold Coast has received world recognition for this scheme in its Pimpama-Coomera suburbs.Gold Coast Water has also been recognised for its world leading HACCP water quality management system by the World Health Organization which published Gold Coast Water's system as a good model for managing water quality and safety from catchment to tap. The Gold Coast desalination plant
column3: which opened in February 2009
column4: has the capacity to supply up to 133 megalitres of desalinated water per day.

column1: === Transport ===
The car is the dominant mode of transport in the Gold Coast
column2: with over 70% of people using it as their sole mode of travelling to work. The Gold Coast has an extensive network of arterial roads that link coastal suburbs with inland suburbs. In recent the years the local and state governments have invested money in transport infrastructure on the Gold Coast to combat the increasing congestion on many of the city's roads. The Gold Coast has an extensive public transport network that includes buses
column3: heavy rail & the new light rail for commuting to work
column4: visiting attractions

column1: A number of major roads connect the Gold Coast with Brisbane
column2: New South Wales
column3: and the surrounding areas. The Pacific Motorway (M1) is the main motorway in the area. Beginning at the Logan Motorway (M6) in Brisbane
column4: it travels through the inland Gold Coast region and links with the Pacific Highway at the New South Wales/Queensland border near Tweed Heads. Before the Tugun Bypass was completed in 2008
column5: the motorway ended at Tugun. The Gold Coast Highway services the coastal suburbs of the Gold Coast
column7: Southport
column8: and Burleigh Heads. Starting at the Pacific Motorway at Tweed Heads
column9: it runs parallel to the coast until it reaches Labrador
column10: where it turns inland to meet the Pacific Motorway again at Helensvale. Other arterial roads include the Smith Street Motorway which connects Southport
column11: Gold Coast’s CBD with the M1 in Parkwood. Other major roads include Reedy Creek Road

column1: ==== Light rail ====
The Gold Coast's light rail service is called G:link
column2: a 20 km (12 mi) line between Helensvale and Broadbeach that also connects the key activity centres of Southport and Surfers Paradise. The G:link was opened in 2014 between Broadbeach and Southport
column3: with an extension to Helensvale completed in 2017 in preparation for the 2018 Commonwealth Games.

column1: ==== Heavy rail ====
Queensland Rail operates rail services from Brisbane to the Gold Coast along the Gold Coast railway line. The line follows the same route as Brisbane's Beenleigh railway line
column2: continuing on after reaching Beenleigh. It then follows a route similar to that of the Pacific Motorway
column3: passing stations at Ormeau
column4: Coomera
column6: Nerang and Robina before terminating at Varsity Lakes. An extension of the Gold Coast line to the Gold Coast Airport is proposed.

column1: The Gold Coast's main provider of public bus services is Surfside Buslines. It is a part of the TransLink network that coordinates the public transport in South East Queensland. Services are frequent during the day
column2: with intervals being as little as 5 minutes between Southport and Burleigh Heads.

column1: ==== Airport ====
Gold Coast Airport is located at Coolangatta
column2: approximately 22 kilometres (14 mi) south of Surfers Paradise. Services are provided to interstate capitals and major cities as well as to major New Zealand cities
column3: Malaysia
column4: Japan and Singapore. It is the sixth busiest airport in Australia.

column1: === Projects ===
The Gold Coast has been debating a controversial cruise ship terminal
A third extension of the G:link to Burleigh Heads is planned with fesability studies and community consultation currently underway.
The existing heavy rail Gold Coast line will be extended to Coolangatta
